title: Third Council of Constantinople
description: The Sixth Ecumenical Council, affirming that Christ has two wills and two operations (680â€“681).

content.text: Convened in Constantinople, this council addressed the Monothelite controversy, which claimed that Christ has only one will.

items: Confessed that Jesus Christ possesses two natural wills (divine and human) and two natural operations, corresponding to his two natures.
Taught that Christ's human will is not abolished or opposed, but freely and perfectly obedient to the divine will.
Condemned Monothelitism and related formulations as inadequate to the church's Christological faith.

content.text: The council extended Chalcedonian logic: if Christ is fully divine and fully human, both natures must be complete. This includes a true human will and operation in the one person of Christ.
